items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels have risen at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight 15/03/2023. We expect river levels to remain high beyond 16/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff have closed the pointing doors at Torksey. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:30 tonight, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Flooding is possible in this area. 
 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.  
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise overnight Wednesday (15/03/23) due to prolonged rain, falling on already saturated ground.
Areas most at risk include Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington, the Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth and the River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot.
Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible from the early hours of Thursday morning (16/03/23), continuing through the day.
We do not currently expect flood warning thresholds to be reached.
Rainfall amounts are expected to be less on Friday (17/03/23) which should allow river levels to recede.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor river levels and this alert will be updated on Friday or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: This alert has been removed as levels on the River Ure have fallen below flood levels. Further rain is expected on Thursday and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to exercise caution around any standing floodwater.

Flooding is possible in this area. 
 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Lake levels on Derwentwater are currently high following heavy rainfall earlier this week. Further rain is now expected to set in during this evening (15/03/23), turning particularly heavy and persistent overnight especially over high ground. We are likely to receive 40-70 mm of rainfall, with the wettest localities possibly receiving in excess of 100 mm of rainfall in 12-18 hours through till late Thursday afternoon.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site which has already been subject to flooding.
We will continue to monitor water levels closely as we expect them to rise above Flood Warning levels again during tomorrow morning with levels not likely to peak till late Thursday night.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near the lake shore and local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Thursday 16/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Heavy rainfall is forecast over the high ground of the Lake District from Wednesday evening (15/03/23) through into Thursday afternoon. Further flooding to low lying land and roads is possible with upland rivers and streams expected to begin to respond during the early hours of Thursday morning (16/03/23) and will remain high throughout the morning. The level of Derwentwater will also rise again throughout Thursday and a Flood Warning remains in force for Keswick Campsite and areas adjacent the lake shores. We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and we will closely monitor the situation. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and do not put yourself in unnecessary danger.
This message will be updated on Friday 17/03/23 or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise overnight Wednesday (15/03/23) due to prolonged rain, falling on already saturated ground.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible from the early hours of Thursday morning (16/03/23), continuing throughout the day.
It is possible that some flood warning thresholds could be reached.
Rainfall amounts are expected to be less on Friday (17/03/23) which should allow river levels to recede.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor river levels and this alert will be updated on Friday or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high on the River Ouse due to recent rain and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. Levels have peaked and are expected to continue falling overnight into Thursday, 16/03/2023. Further rain is forecast overnight and on Thursday morning, and levels are expected to rise again Thursday evening into Friday 17/03/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this warning if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday, 16/03/2023.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault and Welney river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Wednesday 15 March, and is likely to continue for the next few days. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes including the causeways at Sutton Gault and Welney. This information is correct as of 15:30 on Wednesday 15 March. The Welney causeway currently has 37cm of water on the road and the causeway at Sutton Gault has 39cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Further rainfall is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 16/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 16/03/23, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and will update this message as required. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Recent rainfall overnight has caused the River Dee to rise. It should peak at about noon today15 March 2023 at 8.7 metres but will continue to be high until Friday morning 17th March fluctuating between 8.5 and 8.7 metres due to further rainfall tonight and tomorrow. Access to Townfield Lane is currently cut off. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated Friday morning, 17/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning, Thursday 16th March. Water levels continue to remain high and still rising in some areas. We do expect levels to start dropping back down to more normal levels over the next few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 16th March.

This flood alert has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise on the River Seven due to rainfall this evening, Wednesday 15/03/23. Flooding is possible along the River Seven, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, and including properties in Sinnington and to the East of Normanby. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow and into Friday which may keep levels high in the area. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 16/03/2023.

items.message: Over the last week we have seen heavy rainfall and snow melt in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or out buildings is possible close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.
